case_name: Past director and Managing Director of Bank of Commerce Ltd. v. Official Liquidator

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 28 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 28 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 21, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 811 of 1953.

KAPUR J.-This appeal by special leave raises a question of interpretation of s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act.

issues.text: question of interpretation of s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: KAPUR J.-This appeal by special leave raises a question of interpretation of s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act.

issues.text: whether the prosecution was ab initio void because of the absence of prior direction judicially given by the High Court under s. 237 of the Indian Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for quashing the criminal proceedings on the ground that the prosecution was ab initio void because of the absence of prior direction judicially given by the High Court under s. 237 1  of the Indian Companies Act.

issues.text: whether the provisions of s. 237 are a bar to a prosecution by the liquidator

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found against the appellants and discharged the rule. The learned Chief Justice held that the provisions of s. 237 1  are not a bar to a prosecution by the liquidator

anchor.surface_text: nor is it the intention of that section to impinge on the powers of a criminal court under the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.text: Section 237(1) of the Indian Companies Act provides a permissive power for the court to direct the liquidator to prosecute or refer to the registrar; it is not a mandatory condition precedent for the liquidator to institute prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: All that sub-s.  1  requires is that if the Court finds in- the course of winding up that any past or present director, etc., has been guilty of any offence in relation to the company the Court may either on the application

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of 'may direct'; no prohibitory language barring prosecution without direction; distinguished from voluntary winding up provisions; harmonious with CrPC and s.179.

holdings.text: The prosecution is not ab initio void due to absence of prior direction under s.237(1); the complaint by the liquidator suffers from no infirmity making proceedings null and void.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that both on the language of s. 237 1  as well as on precedent the complaint made by the liquidator against the appellants suffers from no such infirmity as to make the proceedings null and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No words in s.237 requiring sanction as precondition; follows precedents (Jaswantrai, Bishan Sahai, Mrityunjoy); rejects Nazir Ahmad analogy.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.237 are not a bar to prosecution by the liquidator, nor do they impinge on criminal courts' powers under CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: nor is it the intention of that section to impinge on the powers of a criminal court under the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permissive language; no prohibitory words like CrPC ss.196/197; s.179 independently empowers liquidator.

holdings.text: No opportunity need be given to the accused before the court gives a direction under s.237(1); hearing is not a prerequisite.

anchor.surface_text: Giving an opportunity to the offender before such direction is given by the Court is not a prerequisite of the Judge making in order under sub-s.  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso applies only to registrar under sub-s.(6), not court direction under sub-s.(1); ex parte application possible per commentary and practice.

holdings.text: The order of Bannerji J. dated July 22, 1952, is a proper and valid direction under s.237(1), as relevant facts and materials were placed before him.

anchor.surface_text: On July 22, 1952, the official liquidator obtained the order from Bannerji J. which the High Court has held, and in our opinion rightly,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order refers to Adhikary report and affidavits containing relevant facts; court applied mind; High Court judgment confirms.

holdings.text: Section 179 deals with powers of the liquidator to institute prosecutions (with court sanction), while s.237 deals with powers of the court to give directions.

anchor.surface_text: Section 179 as the learned Chief Justice of Calcutta High Court has rightly pointed out, deals with the powers of liquidators to institute or defend proceedings with the sanction of the Court and s. 237 1  deals with the powers of the Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear textual distinction; s.179 sufficient basis even absent s.237; Bachawat J. order under s.179 authorizes.

holdings.text: Even in the absence of directions under s.237, the legality of criminal proceedings instituted by the official liquidator is not affected.

anchor.surface_text: As we have said above even in the absence of such directions the legality of the criminal proceedings instituted would not be affected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative from language, precedents, and scheme of Act; no invalidity without direction.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Choudhuri then relied on an observation of Buckley J. In Re London and Globe Finance Corporation  1  also quoted in Sircar Sens book at page 625. There the principles guiding the Court in ordering prosecutions have been laid down as follows I have next to companysider upon what principles I ought to exercise the power given me by S. 167 of the Companies Act, 1862, to direct the official receiver to institute and companduct a prosecution at the expense of the assets.

precedents.case_name: Re London and Globe Finance Corporation
precedents.cited_proposition: principles guiding the Court in ordering prosecutions: not for personal profit or vengeance, but for punishment and deterrence

precedents.citation: re Northern Counties Bank Limited 1   1883  31 W.R. 546

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Choudhuri then relied on certain English cases dealing with the mode of giving directions. In re Northern Counties Bank Limited 1  the Judge had ordered the liquidator to ascertain by circular the wishes of the creditors and after they had appeared to oppose the starting of the prosecution, it was held  1  that it did number sufficiently appear that the offence had been companymitted and  2  that as 2/3 of the creditors opposed the application the prosecution should number be ordered as expenses will have to be paid from out of the money belonging to the creditors.

precedents.cited_proposition: prosecution not ordered where offence not clear and creditors oppose due to expense from company assets

anchor.surface_text: It was next companytended that although the language of s. 237 was number in the negative form still the effect of the words was that numberprosecution companyld be instituted without the sanction of the Court being obtained by the liquidator. Cubitt  1  which was a case under the Sea Fisheries Act which created certain offences and by s. 11 provided The provisions of this Act shall be enforced by sea-fishery officers , who are defined by that section and it was held that the effect of the words was that numberone except the sea-fishery officer companyld prosecute an offence under the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: statutory words 'shall be enforced by' certain officers mean only they can prosecute

precedents.cited_proposition: order under statute can only be made by person within specific statutory words

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also relied on Nazir Ahmad v. Crown  3  where it was held that if the statute authorises the doing of an act in one way then it had to be done in that way or number at all. The argument of Mr. Choudhuri really companyes to this that the companyplaint filed on behalf of the official liquidator was incompetent in the absence of a direction under s. 237 or without companyplying with the procedure laid down in that section.

precedents.cited_proposition: if statute authorizes act in one way, must be done that way or not at all

precedents.cited_proposition: neither s.179 nor s.237 makes liquidator's action without court direction illegal or invalidating prosecution

anchor.surface_text: It was further urged on behalf of the respondents that in the case before us there was a proper direction under s. 237 1 . The judgment of the High Court shows that before the learned Judge gave a direction on July 22, 1952, there were before him proper materials and, therefore, his sanction was perfectly valid, legal and proper. Before this order made by Bannerji J. there was an order of Bachawat J. dated January 15, 1951, under s. 179 and, therefore, when the liquidator authorised his Assistant, respondent No. 1 to institute the proceedings he was entitled to do so. As we have said above even in the absence of such directions the legality of the criminal proceedings instituted would number be affected.

outcome.relief_summary: Criminal proceedings by official liquidator held valid even without prior direction under s.237(1) of Companies Act; High Court order upheld

anchor.surface_text: All that sub-s.  1  requires is that if the Court finds in- the course of winding up that any past or present director, etc., has been guilty of any offence in relation to the company the Court may either on the application

It was further urged on behalf of the respondents that in the case before us there was a proper direction under s. 237 1 . The judgment of the High Court shows that before the learned Judge gave a direction on July 22, 1952, there were before him proper materials and, therefore, his sanction was perfectly valid, legal and proper. Before this order made by Bannerji J. there was an order of Bachawat J. dated January 15, 1951, under s. 179 and, therefore, when the liquidator authorised his Assistant, respondent No. 1 to institute the proceedings he was entitled to do so. As we have said above even in the absence of such directions the legality of the criminal proceedings instituted would number be affected.

It would thus appear that both on the language of s. 237 1  as well as on precedent the complaint made by the liquidator against the appellants suffers from no such infirmity as to make the proceedings null and void.

It was further urged on behalf of the respondents that in the case before us there was a proper direction under s. 237 1 . The judgment of the High Court shows that before the learned Judge gave a direction on July 22, 1952, there were before him proper materials and, therefore, his sanction was perfectly valid, legal and proper. Before this order made by Bannerji J. there was an order of Bachawat J. dated January 15, 1951, under s. 179 and, therefore, when the liquidator authorised his Assistant, respondent No. 1 to institute the proceedings he was entitled to do so. As we have said above even in the absence of such directions the legality of the criminal proceedings instituted would number be affected.

anchor.surface_text: Section 179 as the learned Chief Justice of Calcutta High Court has rightly pointed out, deals with the powers of liquidators to institute or defend proceedings with the sanction of the Court and s. 237 1  deals with the powers of the Court
